results.content:
I love how direct & information your lectures are.  No frills, straight  to the point learning - and for this particular language, it makes all the sense in the world. 

As someone who's worked through numerous Udemy programming courses, it IS refreshing! All I recommend is to Continually update the content - Go will adopt Generics by year end, which is one of the biggest changest to the language since its inception.  Please keep refreshing material.  Thank you again!!!! <3

results.content: This course is an absolute gem. I'm a frontend developer that has years of experience with javascript. I wanted to learn go to separate myself from the js ecosystem and have more opportunities. I didn't just want to know frontend and node.js. So I chose go (a lot of companies that are using vue.js are also using go) and got this course. It is practical, the instructor is knowledgeable and has a great teaching style. I definitely recommend this to anyone wanting to learn the language and have fun along the way.

I highly recommend to anyone that wants to learn Go.

results.content:
這位老師講解的很好，但如果是完全不懂程式的新手，建議先學Python把一些Coding的概念搞懂，Go雖然簡單，但是不適合完全沒寫過程式的新手(當然如果自認天選之人那就沒差)。
此課程操作部分非常實用，不過有些方法的小黃線警告未處理，是不影響編譯啦，但警告就是官方建議的使用方式，還是建議除錯一下(後來自己查官方API文件解決了)。
Web的部分老師直接講Go自帶的標準函式庫，這點很不錯，一些YouTube的影片教Golang的Web都是用第三方套件，其實Go自帶的套件學好就很好用了(也讓你看起來比較厲害XD)！

results.content: This is a course suitable for every developer who's first language was Golang. My first language was Golang, I knew the syntax well, but didnt know what to do with it. And there are VERY few courses online that teach you web development with GO... but only the basics. Trevor has made a classy course just like the one's you'd see for python or node js full stack. If Go is your first language and you want to also learn about web development, this is THE course to take. And also the course with react looks amazing (my next one for sure)

results.content:
This course is good but feels extremely exhausting. The instructor often inclines towards what he wants and not what will give the most value to the students. 
Most applications these days will be built as APIs and the clients will be built with more mature frontend frameworks like React, Vue or Angular. But the instructor goes for the more traditional approach of building applications using bootstrap and vanilla JS. Not bad for fundamentals but that totally deviates from what the course is supposed to offer, i.e Go.

This course could have been much better if it focussed on building APIs in GO and the instructor used a REST API client e.g postman, thunder, insomnia or whichever other. After building the APIs, the course could have then built the webpages to consume it. But now all that html, csss and js monotony is strewn in the middle and skipping it means you will have to give up on any go tips and tricks in there - yet going through the whole thing is extremely tiring.

The instructor goes on to choose postgres yet mysql has a bigger audience and all the time I am just hoping that he would give us more reasons as to why he is opting for Postgres. Not that I hate these technologies but if I buy a course and the lecturer is opting for a tech, I would love to know the merits it brings and what I stand to lose or gain if I choose one over the other. I dont want to use Postgres simply because, "Thats what I want to use". I also dont want to use DBeaver, which has one of the worst UIs ever, unless it offers certain advantages. This wouldn't bother me if the instructor would just indicate that we use whatever we want as long as we can view our DBs. But he doesnt do that, he goes through the process of installing and setting up, which is again monotonous.

The instructor is knowledgable and honestly he has jokes, puns and sarcasm that had me laughing more than once. But this is not a Kevin Hart special, its a Go course and at the end I just gave up on it. It really felt like school and that the instructor made a course for Udemy and not for sofwtare engineers looking to learn Go.

Another thing that couldve helped ease the monotony is build multiple apps as we learn new concepts. That way, students can easily skip an app if it touches on concepts they are familiar with. But in this case the instructor built one app, making skipping lessons a tedious thing to do.
results.content_html:

Most applications these days will be built as APIs and the clients will be built with more mature frontend frameworks like React, Vue or Angular. But the instructor goes for the more traditional approach of building applications using bootstrap and vanilla JS. Not bad for fundamentals but that totally deviates from what the course is supposed to offer, i.e Go.

This course could have been much better if it focussed on building APIs in GO and the instructor used a REST API client e.g postman, thunder, insomnia or whichever other. After building the APIs, the course could have then built the webpages to consume it. But now all that html, csss and js monotony is strewn in the middle and skipping it means you will have to give up on any go tips and tricks in there - yet going through the whole thing is extremely tiring.

The instructor goes on to choose postgres yet mysql has a bigger audience and all the time I am just hoping that he would give us more reasons as to why he is opting for Postgres. Not that I hate these technologies but if I buy a course and the lecturer is opting for a tech, I would love to know the merits it brings and what I stand to lose or gain if I choose one over the other. I dont want to use Postgres simply because, "Thats what I want to use". I also dont want to use DBeaver, which has one of the worst UIs ever, unless it offers certain advantages. This wouldn't bother me if the instructor would just indicate that we use whatever we want as long as we can view our DBs. But he doesnt do that, he goes through the process of installing and setting up, which is again monotonous.

The instructor is knowledgable and honestly he has jokes, puns and sarcasm that had me laughing more than once. But this is not a Kevin Hart special, its a Go course and at the end I just gave up on it. It really felt like school and that the instructor made a course for Udemy and not for sofwtare engineers looking to learn Go.

Another thing that couldve helped ease the monotony is build multiple apps as we learn new concepts. That way, students can easily skip an app if it touches on concepts they are familiar with. But in this case the instructor built one app, making skipping lessons a tedious thing to do.

results.content: Very clean and straightforward explanation. Bought both courses from Trevor. 5/5
results.content_html: Very clean and straightforward explanation. Bought both courses from Trevor. 5/5

results.content: I am not very happy with the way the course material is organised until now. I was expecting more on the backend side of the Go-lang programming but what we have been mostly doing is frontend and template organization.
results.content_html: I am not very happy with the way the course material is organised until now. I was expecting more on the backend side of the Go-lang programming but what we have been mostly doing is frontend and template organization.

results.content:
This course is terribly structured. Some parts look like they have been recorded later and were inserted in the wrong order.
For example the := syntax for assigning variables is used in one lesson without explanation, then used again in the next and the instructor explains it as if it was the first time it was used. Other times the code shown is of a later version, just causing further confusion. VSCode is introduced in the very beginning then completely forgotten. Facecam comes and goes. Some lessons have a lot of background noise, others don't. Some have extremely annoying thunk noises every time the instructor clicks or types something. Everything happens way too quickly to properly understand.

I forced myself through the third section and finally gave up. It starts off promising, introducing the "basics" of serving websites with Go. The instructor then races through implementing HTML Templates, integrating Bootstrap in 50 seconds (as the instructor puts it: "Just very quickly use this link here..."), completely refactoring everything into packages (which were introduced earlier, but then apparently not used, and now "properly introduced"), creating layouts, building a template cache, application wide configuration with the Repository pattern ("Seems confusing at first, but hopefully by the time I go through it a couple of times it will make sense to you" is the explanation given), sharing data with templates...

All of this happens in Section 3, helpfully titled "Building a *Basic* Web Application. Racing through so many topics in about 2 hours, with very little indepth explanation given, the speed of the instructor's speech, the absolutely terrible variable names (I hope you remember w is the ResponseWriter and t is a template, tc for templatecache) and useless comments (main is the main application function) just left me with a headache by the end of that section.

If I had come to this course as a complete beginner I couldn't imagine getting anything out of this.

This course needs some serious reorganizing. Put the courses in proper order and re-record the courses with bad audio. Give us some deeper explanations about what is actually happening, an effort was made in the beginning of the third section with the request/response lifecycle, but nothing else in the section has diagrams. Break up the third section into smaller parts and spend more time on actually explaining those parts.

I wouldn't recommend this course at its current state.

response.content: I'm sorry you feel that way. While it is true that I have gone back to improve some of the lectures, and will continue to do so, I am reasonably certain that everything is in the correct order. I have been designing and delivering courses for quite a few years now. Also, I do have to note that you never once asked for clarification or help, which I am happy to offer. Finally, the variable naming conventions that I use are the norm in the Go world. But thanks for your detailed comment.
response.content_html: I'm sorry you feel that way. While it is true that I have gone back to improve some of the lectures, and will continue to do so, I am reasonably certain that everything is in the correct order. I have been designing and delivering courses for quite a few years now. Also, I do have to note that you never once asked for clarification or help, which I am happy to offer. Finally, the variable naming conventions that I use are the norm in the Go world. But thanks for your detailed comment.

Other times the code shown is of a later version, just causing further confusion. VSCode is introduced in the very beginning then completely forgotten. Facecam comes and goes. Some lessons have a lot of background noise, others don't. Some have extremely annoying thunk noises every time the instructor clicks or types something. The instructor then races through implementing HTML Templates, integrating Bootstrap in 50 seconds (as the instructor puts it: "Just very quickly use this link here..."), completely refactoring everything into packages (which were introduced earlier, but then apparently not used, and now "properly introduced"), creating layouts, building a template cache, application wide configuration with the Repository pattern ("Seems confusing at first, but hopefully by the time I go through it a couple of times it will make sense to you" is the explanation given), sharing data with templates...

All of this happens in Section 3, helpfully titled "Building a *Basic* Web Application. Racing through so many topics in about 2 hours, with very little indepth explanation given, the speed of the instructor's speech, the absolutely terrible variable names (I hope you remember w is the ResponseWriter and t is a template, tc for templatecache) and useless comments (main is the main application function) just left me with a headache by the end of that section.
